questions.question: A karyotyping image is given below. What are the clinical features most likely to be expected in such patients?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Gynecomastia and long limbs Explanation: The karyotype image reveals an additional X chromosome, confirming the presence of Klinefelter Syndrome (47, XXY), a condition often associated with features like gynecomastia and longer limbs. It is male hypogonadism resulting from two or more X chromosomes and one or more Y chromosomes. It is an important genetic cause of reduced spermatogenesis and male infertility. Karyotype: The most common is 47, XXY, from meiotic nondisjunction; some have mosaic patterns (e.g., 46, XY/47, XXY). X chromosome genes: Some genes escape inactivation, leading to uneven dosage compensation and overexpression. Clinical features of Klinefelter syndrome: Gynecomastia (breast development) Long limbs Infertility (most common cause of male hypogonadism and infertility). Flat occiput (Option B) is a feature of Down syndrome (Trisomy 21), a genetic condition caused by an extra chromosome 21, leading to intellectual disability, developmental delays, and physical traits like a flat face and almond-shaped eyes. It’s linked to heart defects, hearing loss, and other health issues. Webbing of the neck and lymphedema (Option C) are features of Turner’s syndrome, a genetic condition that occurs when a female is born with only one full X chromosome (45, X instead of the usual 46, XX). It leads to short stature, infertility, and sometimes heart defects,

questions.question: What is the interpretation of the given pedigree chart?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Autosomal dominant Explanation: The interpretation of the pedigree chart given reveals Autosomal dominant inheritance , which means that an individual only needs one copy of the mutated gene to express the condition. Affected individuals appear in every generation, as one parent passes on the mutated gene to their offspring. Both males and females can be affected equally because the gene is located on one of the autosomes . If an affected person has children, there is a 50% chance that each child will inherit the mutated gene and be affected. Autosomal Recessive (Option B) inheritance is where the Individuals usually do not express the trait unless they inherit two copies of the mutation . This inheritance pattern typically has horizontal transmission and skip generations in between. X-linked recessive (Option C) disorders affect males more than females because males have only one X chromosome. Females need two copies of the mutation to be affected. Additionally, X-linked recessive disorders often show a pattern where affected males pass the mutated gene to all their daughters but none of their sons. X-linked dominan t (Option D) inheritance means an affected female can pass the condition to both sons and daughters, while an affected male passes it to all daughters but none of his sons. The question contradicts this pattern, so X-linked dominant is not the correct answer.

questions.question: A 30-year-old pregnant woman who has the thalassemia trait visits the clinic for genetic counselling. Her husband is also confirmed to have the thalassemia trait. Considering their genetic background, what is the likelihood of their next offspring having thalassemia?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 25% Explanation: There is a 25% chance that their child will inherit the genotype β I / β I , corresponding to β -thalassemia major . Mother's Genotype: β / β I (carrier for β -thalassemia) Father's Genotype: β / β I (carrier for β -thalassemia) Punnett Square Analysis β β I β β / β β / β I β I β / β I β I / β I Possible Outcomes: β / β (Normal): 25% β / β I (Carrier): 50% β I / β I ( β -thalassemia major): 25% Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 145

questions.question: Which of the following correctly represents the effect of the mutation causing sickle cell anaemia?

options.A: Glutamate by valine at the 6th position
options.B: Valine by glutamate at the 6th position
options.C: Glutamate by valine at the 5th position
options.D: Valine by glutamate at the 5th position

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Glutamate by valine at the 6th position Explanation: Sickle cell anaemia is caused by a point mutation that involves substituting adenine for thymine at the sixth codon of the β -globin gene (GAG to GTG) , replacing glutamic acid (glutamate) with valine in the β -globin chain of haemoglobin. This single nucleotide change results in the formation of abnormal haemoglobin molecules (HbS) . After deoxygenation, HbS molecules polymerize to form bundles. These polymer bundles cause erythrocytes to adopt a sickle shape and also promote hemolysis of erythrocytes, releasing cell-free Hb into circulation. Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th Edition, Pages 142,143

questions.question: B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time. Which phenomenon is it due to?
questions.explanation: process allows the same gene for the heavy chain to be spliced in different ways to produce both IgM and IgD isotypes. The IgM and IgD are both produced from the same heavy chain gene but are differentiated through this splicing mechanism. During this process, the RNA transcript for the heavy chain is spliced in two different ways, one to produce IgM and the other to produce IgD . Both these antibodies have the same antigen-binding specificity but differ in their constant regions, which define their isotypes. Somatic hypermutation (Option A) occurs after antigen exposure and increases antibody affinity, but it does not affect the simultaneous expression of IgM and IgD. Affinity maturation (Option C) is a process that occurs during the immune response to improve the affinity of antibodies, not to generate multiple antibody classes at the same time. Allelic exclusion (Option D) ensures that only one allele of the immunoglobulin gene is expressed in a B cell at any given time, which helps in maintaining clonal specificity, but it does not explain the co-expression of IgM and IgD. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4730250/ Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 203, 591

questions.question: Differential expression of a gene depending upon the parent of origin is a feature of:
questions.explanation: parent the gene was inherited from. In imprinted genes, one allele is silenced depending on the parent of origin, leading to differential expression. Genomic imprinting: Inheritance : We inherit two copies of each autosomal gene, one from each parent, but functional differences can exist between the maternal and paternal alleles. Mechanism: Imprinting is an epigenetic process that selectively inactivates either the maternal or paternal allele. Maternal imprinting silences the maternal allele, while paternal imprinting silences the paternal allele. Imprinting occurs in the ovum or sperm before fertilization. The imprinting pattern is stably transmitted to somatic cells through mitosis. Imprinting is linked to disorders like Prader-Willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome. Prader-Willi syndrome Chromosome 15q SNORP gene Paternal deletion Maternal imprinting Angelman syndrome Chromosome 15q UBE3A gene Maternal deletion Paternal imprinting Gonadal mosaicism (Option A) refers to a condition where some of an individual's gametes (eggs or sperm) carry a mutation that is not present in the somatic cells. It does not involve differential expression based on the parent of origin, which is specific to genomic imprinting. Anticipation (Option C) refers to the phenomenon where a genetic disorder becomes more severe or appears at an earlier age with each successive generation. It is seen in trinucleotide repeat disorders. Incomplete penetrance (Option D) refers to situations where an individual with a disease-causing genotype does not show the expected phenotype. Example: BRCA1 gene mutations , which increase the risk of breast and ovarian cancer. Some individuals with the mutation never develop cancer despite carrying the gene. Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 178

questions.question: Which of the following disorders is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern?
questions.explanation: dominant inheritance: The gene responsible for the concerned trait or disorder is present on the X chromosome and can express itself both in homozygous and heterozygous conditions. It is more commonly seen in females than males since females have two X chromosomes. An affected male will transmit the disease to all his daughters but not sons. An affected female can transmit the disease to both daughters and sons. Conditions with X-linked dominant inheritance: Rett syndrome . Alport syndrome Vitamin D-resistant rickets. Incontinentia pigmenti. The pedigree chart below shows an X-linked dominant pattern: The affected mother of the first generation transmitted the disease to both son and daughter. The affected father of the second generation transmitted the disease only to the daughters. Duchenne muscular dystrophy (Option B) follows an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern. Huntington’s disease (Option C) follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. Tuberous sclerosis (Option D) is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Learning Objective: X-linked dominance is more common in females. Affected males transmit the disease only to their daughters. Affected females transmit the disease to both daughters and sons. Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 146

questions.question: In cystic fibrosis, which of the following structures is affected in the pancreas?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) B Explanation: "B" represents the acini, the functional units of the exocrine pancreas that produce and secrete digestive enzymes into the pancreatic ducts, and these are affected in Cystic Fibrosis, an autosomal recessive genetic disorder. Pathogenesis: It is caused by mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene, resulting in a defect in the production or function of the CFTR protein. This leads to thick, sticky mucus forming in various organs, including the pancreas. In the pancreas, the defective CFTR protein affects the secretion of chloride ions and water, dehydrating pancreatic secretions. This thickened mucus obstructs the pancreatic ducts, preventing the proper flow of digestive enzymes from the acini into the duodenum. (Option B) Consequently, there is a reduction in the production and release of pancreatic enzymes, leading to impaired digestion and malabsorption of nutrients. Clinical features: Respiratory system Gastrointestinal and hepatic Others Progressive airway obstruction Infective exacerbations of bronchiectasis Respiratory failure Spontaneous pneumothorax Haemoptysis Lobar collapse due to secretions Pulmonary hypertension Nasal polyps Malabsorption and steatorrhoea Distal intestinal obstruction syndrome Biliary cirrhosis Portal hypertension, varices, and splenomegaly Gallstones Diabetes Delayed puberty, Male infertility Stress incontinence due to repeated forced cough Psychosocial problems Osteoporosis Arthropathy Cutaneous vasculitis A (Option A) is the islets of Langerhans, responsible for the production and secretion of hormones such as insulin and glucagon. It is not the target of cystic fibrosis. C (Option C) is the intralobular duct, which is part of the pancreatic duct system and plays a role in transporting pancreatic enzymes. It is not the target of cystic fibrosis. D (Option D) is the interlobular duct that transports pancreatic secretions and is not the target of cystic fibrosis. Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th Edition, Page 466-471.

questions.question: A girl presents with short stature, a webbed neck, thick calves, a shield-shaped chest, swelling of the ankle, and an increased carrying angle. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Turner syndrome Explanation: The clinical features described are characteristic of Turner syndrome , which is a genetic condition caused by the partial or complete absence of one of the X chromosomes (45 XO karyotype). It leads to hypogonadism in phenotypic females. Features of Turner Syndrome: Down syndrome (Option B) results from Trisomy 21. It is associated with features such as intellectual disability , epicanthal folds , flat facial profile , and congenital heart defects but does not include the specific skeletal and physical features seen in Turner syndrome. Patau syndrome (Option C) occurs due to trisomy 13 , and its clinical features include microphthalmia, microcephaly, rocker bottom feet, polycystic kidney disease, and congenital heart disease , none of which are consistent with the features described in the question. Edward syndrome (Option D) is caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 18 (Trisomy 18) and is characterized by severe developmental delay, clenched fists , rocker-bottom feet , and heart defects , which differ significantly from the features seen in Turner syndrome.

questions.question: The family pedigree chart is given below. Identify the mode of inheritance of this condition.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Autosomal dominant Explanation: The disease is transmitted from father to son, ruling out X-linked inheritance & the condition appears in every generation, with both males & females affected, suggesting an autosomal dominant pattern. Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern: The mode of transmission is vertical . An affected person has an affected parent. There is a 50% chance of the dominant trait being transmitted to offspring. Both males and females are equally affected. The dominant gene is expressed in heterozygotes. Delayed age of onset. The trait appears in every generation without skipping. An unaffected offspring does not transmit the disease. questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct about Huntington's chorea?

options.A: It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder
options.B: There is a loss of function type of mutation
options.C: There are abnormal length repeats of CUG
options.D: Abnormality is seen due to a defect in chromosome 6

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder Explanation: Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide repeat disorder caused by the expansion of the CAG repeat in the HTT gene on chromosome 4. Huntington's disease: HD is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by the degeneration of striatal neurons, leading to a progressive movement disorder and dementia. Symptoms include chorea , bradykinesia, and rigidity. It is relentlessly progressive and fatal, typically over 15 years. Pathogenesis: HD is a trinucleotide repeat expansion disease caused by a CAG repeat (Option C) in the HTT gene on chromosome 4p16.3 (Option D) , encoding huntingtin protein . Normal HTT genes have 6 to 35 CAG repeats , while pathogenic mutations have expanded repeats, leading to earlier disease onset with paternal transmission causing anticipation & the toxic gain-of-function (Option B) of mutant huntingtin is believed to be the primary pathogenic mechanism. Morphology: The brain exhibits atrophy of the caudate nucleus and putamen , along with ventricular dilation . There is a loss of striatal neurons , particularly affecting GABAergic neurons in the caudate and putamen. Gliosis is more extensive than usual due to neuronal loss. Clinical features: The loss of striatal neurons results in increased motor activity, causing choreoathetosis . Cognitive decline follows, with symptoms such as forgetfulness and dementia . The disease usually manifests in the fourth or fifth decade , and motor symptoms typically precede cognitive symptoms . The leading cause of death is often pneumonia , especially in advanced stages. Suicide rates are higher in HD patients. Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 174, 1285

questions.question: Premature ageing in Werner syndrome is due to:

options.C: Increase in length of telomere due to decrease in telomerase activity

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Defect in DNA helicase Explanation: Werner syndrome , a rare autosomal recessive disorder, is characterised by premature ageing and accelerated development of age-related diseases. It results from mutations in the WRN gene, which encodes a DNA helicase involved in DNA repair and maintenance of genomic stability. Chromosomal damage accumulates rapidly due to the defective enzyme. This damage mimics normal ageing at a faster rate, leading to premature ageing. Similar conditions like Bloom syndrome and ataxia-telangiectasia also involve mutations in genes responsible for DNA repair . These disorders result in genetic instability and accelerated ageing due to impaired DNA repair mechanisms. Incorrect Options: Increased telomerase activity (Option A) is typically seen in some cancers, where it allows cells to maintain telomere length and avoid senescence. Increase in length of telomere due to decrease in telomerase activity (Option C) and Decreased telomerase activity (Option D) : In Werner syndrome, telomere shortening occurs due to DNA repair defects rather than telomere maintenance problems. Telomerase activity is not significantly altered. Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 67

questions.question: What is the mode of inheritance in a patient suffering from colour blindness?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) XLR Explanation: The mode of inheritance in a patient suffering from colour blindness is X-linked recessive (XLR). X-Linked Recessive : The gene for Color blindness is located on the X chromosome. Males (XY) express the disorder if they inherit the affected X chromosome since they lack a second X for compensation. Females (XX) can be carriers if they inherit one affected X chromosome, often showing no symptoms due to the normal allele on the other X. Affected males cannot pass the disorder to sons but can pass the affected X to daughters, making them carriers. X-linked Recessive (WISE ABCDEFGH) Wise- Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome AB- Hemophilia A, B B- Bruton's Hypogammaglobulinemia . C- Chronic Granulomatous Disease, Red Green Color Blindness D- DMD, BMD E- Lesch Nyhan Syndrome F- Fabry Disease, Fragile X Syndrome G- G6PD Deficiency H- Hunter Disease Incorrect Options: Autosomal Dominant (AD) (Option A) disorders affect both sexes equally , and only one mutated allele is required for the disease to manifest. Examples: Marfan syndrome, Achondroplasia, Familial hypercholesterolemia . Autosomal Recessive (AR) (Option B) disorders require both alleles to be mutated for disease manifestation. Examples: Cystic fibrosis, Sickle cell disease, Phenylketonuria (PKU) . Colour blindness is inherited in an X-linked pattern, not AR. X-linked Dominant (XLD) (Option D) affects both males and females , but females more commonly due to having two X chromosomes. Examples: Rett syndrome, Fragile X syndrome, and Hypophosphatemic rickets . Colour blindness is X-linked recessive, not dominant. Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th Edition, Page 146

questions.question: t(11,22) is best diagnosed by …………..
questions.explanation: specific DNA sequences. In the case of t(11,22) translocation, FISH can identify the rearrangement by detecting the fusion of the genes involved in the translocation. FISH is highly sensitive and specific for detecting chromosomal abnormalities, even at the level of individual genes. Incorrect Options: Option A. Conventional karyotyping: Conventional karyotyping involves examining the chromosomes' structure and number under a microscope. However, it may not provide sufficient resolution to detect small translocations like t(11,22). Option C . Bone marrow aspiration: Bone marrow aspiration is a procedure to obtain a sample of bone marrow for examination under a microscope. While it can help diagnose certain conditions, it is not the primary method for detecting chromosomal translocations like t(11,22). Option D . Next-generation sequencing (NGS): NGS is a powerful sequencing technology that allows the analysis of multiple genes and genetic variants simultaneously. It is primarily used for genetic testing, including the identification of specific mutations and genetic alterations. While NGS can detect genetic abnormalities, it may not be the most efficient method for diagnosing t(11,22) translocation specifically.

questions.question: Which mutation is linked to the Philadelphia chromosome?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Reciprocal translocation Explanation: The Philadelphia Chromosome is a reciprocal translocation involving chromosomes 9 and 22 that is commonly identified in CML (chronic myeloid leukaemia). The two chromosome breaks lie within: ABL gene on chromosome 9 BCR (breakpoint cluster region) gene on chromosome 22. Nonhomologous end-joining causes a reciprocal translocation , resulting in the formation of an oncogenic BCR-ABL fusion gene on the derivative chromosome 22, known as the Philadelphia chromosome. BCR-ABL fusion genes encode chimeric BCR-ABL proteins with constitutive tyrosine kinase activity. Inversion (Option A): In an inversion, a segment of a chromosome is flipped within the same chromosome but remains in its original location. Example of inversion-related disorder: Hemophilia A (due to intrachromosomal inversion in the F8 gene). Deletion (Option B) involves the loss of a chromosome segment, leading to missing genetic material. Example of deletion-related disorder: Cri-du-chat syndrome (chromosome 5p deletion) Insertion (Option D) occurs when a segment of one chromosome is inserted into another chromosome without reciprocal exchange. Example of insertion-related disorder: Some cases of hereditary cancer syndromes due to gene insertions. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 317.

questions.question: A teenager was brought to the OPD with complaints of delayed fertility and primary amenorrhea. Physical examination reveals a webbed neck and widely spaced nipples. Which karyotype is associated with a given condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 45, X Explanation: The teenager presenting with delayed fertility, primary amenorrhea, a webbed neck, and widely spaced nipples is diagnosed with Turner Syndrome , which is characterised by the karyotype 45, X (monosomy X) . It is characterised by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome, leading to hypogonadism in phenotypic females. Clinical features: Short stature, webbed neck, lymphedema, and primary amenorrhea. The image below shows karyotyping in Turner syndrome. 47, XXY (Option B) is Klinefelter syndrome , which occurs in males with an extra X chromosome, leading to hypogonadism, small testes, gynecomastia, reduced body/facial hair, and infertility. While it is associated with tall stature and sometimes mild intellectual disabilities, it does not present with features like a webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, or primary amenorrhea, which are characteristic of Turner syndrome. 47, XXX (Option C) is Triple X Syndrome , which occurs in females with an extra X chromosome. It is usually asymptomatic or causes mild developmental delays but does not present with primary amenorrhea or webbed neck, which are typical of Turner syndrome. 47, XYY (Option D) is Jacob's Syndrome , which occurs in males with an extra Y chromosome, leading to tall stature and mild intellectual disabilities, but it does not cause primary amenorrhea, webbed neck, or widely spaced nipples, which are characteristic of Turner syndrome.

questions.question: What does the given pedigree chart indicate?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Mitochondrial Disorder Explanation: The given pedigree suggests a Mitochondrial Disorder , where a defect in maternal mtDNA is inherited by all offspring, while a defect in paternal mtDNA is not passed on to any offspring. They involve defects in the mitochondria, which are responsible for producing energy in the form of ATP through oxidative phosphorylation. Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is inherited exclusively from the mother (females with pathogenic mtDNA can pass the disease to their offspring). They affect organs with prominent aerobic metabolism (commonly skeletal muscle (myopathy) and nervous system). Some examples are: Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON) Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO)/ Kearns-Sayre syndrome (KSS) Leigh syndrome Mitochondrial encephalomyopathy with lactic acidosis and stroke-like episodes (MELAS) Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibres (MERRF) Neuropathy, ataxia, and retinitis pigmentosa (NARP) Primary coenzyme Q10 (CoQ10) deficiency The most common mitochondrial disease is MELAS. The most common mitochondrial Myopathy is CPEO (Chronic Progressive External Ophthalmoplegia). questions.question: A child with a strawberry skull, mental retardation, and the given karyotype suggests which diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Edward syndrome Explanation: A child with a "strawberry skull," intellectual disability, and the given karyotype likely has trisomy 18 , indicating a diagnosis of Edwards Syndrome . It is caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 18. Clinical features: Low birth weight Strawberry skull (small chin & prominent occiput/back side of the head). Closed fists with overlapping fingers Rocker-bottom feet Microcephaly Micrognathia Cardiac and renal malformations Mental retardation 95% of cases die in the 1st year of life Patau syndrome (Option A) , caused by trisomy 13 , is characterised by features such as polydactyly (extra fingers), cleft lip and palate, keyhole-shaped pupils/coloboma, intellectual disability, and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), among others. Prader-Willi syndrome (Option C) occurs when there is maternal disomy of chromosome 15, leading to the absence of the paternal allele. Key features include intellectual disability (MR), short stature, and obesity/hyperphagia due to elevated levels of the hormone ghrelin. Angelman syndrome (Option D), often referred to as "Happy Puppet" syndrome , arises when there is a paternal disomy of chromosome 15, leading to the absence of the maternal allele. Key features include seizures, ataxia, intellectual disability (MR), and inappropriate laughter.

questions.question: All of the following are used to detect abnormal gene sequences, except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Flow cytometry Explanation: Flow cytometry is not used to detect abnormal gene sequences . Flow cytometry is a technique primarily used to measure the physical and chemical properties of cells, such as cell size, granularity, and protein expression. It has numerous uses in genomic studies, with a high focus on monitoring cell cycle phases and cell viability, and is more often employed for immunophenotyping and cell sorting. Fluorescence in situ Hybridization (FISH) (Option A) detects DNA sequence alterations like translocations, deletions, and amplifications using fluorescent probes to bind specific DNA regions, identifying chromosomal abnormalities. RFLP analysis (Option B) (Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism) detects DNA sequence variations by analyzing the lengths of restriction enzyme-digested DNA fragments. Pyrosequencing (Option C) is a type of DNA sequencing technology that can directly read DNA sequences by measuring the release of pyrophosphate during nucleotide incorporation. It allows for the detection of mutations, SNPs, and other genetic alterations. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 182 NIH Link

questions.question: What is the interpretation of the given pedigree chart?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Autosomal dominant Explanation: The interpretation of the pedigree chart given reveals Autosomal dominant inheritance , which means that an individual only needs one copy of the mutated gene to express the condition. The affected individuals appear in every generation, as one parent passes on the mutated gene to their offspring. Both males and females can be affected equally because the gene is located on one of the autosomes . If an affected person has children, there is a 50% chance that each child will inherit the mutated gene and be affected. Incomplete penetrance (Option A) refers to a situation where some individuals inherit the mutant gene but are phenotypically normal. Autosomal Recessive (Option C) inheritance requires two copies of the mutation for the trait to be expressed. It typically shows horizontal transmission and can skip generations. Pseudo dominance (Option D) occurs when a recessive allele appears to be expressed in the heterozygous condition due to the limited number of crossovers between linked genes.

questions.question: Match the following genetic abnormalities with their disorders. A. Trinucleotide repeat Patau syndrome B. Trisomy 18 2. Huntington C. Trisomy 13 3. Sickle cell anemia D. Hb beta chain Glu 4. Edward syndrome
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3 Explanation: Trinucleotide repeat Huntington Trisomy 18 Edward syndrome Trisomy 13 Patau syndrome Hb beta chain Glu Sickle cell anemia Trinucleotide repeat disorders : These are caused by the expansion of specific three-nucleotide sequences in genes. They are characterized by the instability of repeat numbers, which can increase across generations or even within an individual’s lifetime, a key feature of these conditions. Examples of Trinucleotide repeat and the disease-associated are: Huntington's disease: CAG Fragile X syndrome: CGG Myotonic dystrophy type 1: CTG Trisomy 18 (Edward syndrome): Features include Low birth weight Closed fists with overlapping fingers Rocker-bottom feet Microcephaly Micrognathia Cardiac and renal malformations Mental retardation 95% of cases die in the 1st year of life Trisomy 13 (Patau Syndrome): Features include Rocker-bottom feet Severe intellectual disability Keyhole/ Coloboma (eyes) Microphthalmia, microcephaly, holoprosencephaly Cleft lip/palate Polydactyly Congenital heart disease Renal defects-Polycystic kidney disease Umbilical hernia, Omphalocele Hb beta chain Glu This mutation is seen in sickle cell anaemia and produces haemoglobin S (HbS), making red blood cells prone to hemolysis. This leads to complications such as splenic fibrosis, organ infarcts, and bone pain due to HbS polymerization and vaso-occlusion. Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic Basis of diseases, 10th Edition, Page 144, 166-169, Pubmed Link Uptodate Link

questions.question: The SRY gene is present on:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Y-chromosome short arm Explanation: The SRY (Sex-determining Region Y) gene is crucial for male sex determination. It is located on the distal short arm of the Y chromosome. Yp11.3 is the precise genetic locus where "Yp" refers to the short arm ( "p" ) of the Y chromosome. Mutations in this gene can lead to disorders of sex development (DSDs), such as Swyer syndrome (46, XY gonadal dysgenesis) . Y-chromosome long arm (Option B) is rich in genes related to male reproductive functions, but the SRY gene is located on the short arm (Yp). X-chromosome short arm (Option C) & X-chromosome long arm (Option D): The X chromosome plays no role in initiating male sex determination . Instead, it carries genes like DAX1 (Xp21), which antagonizes SRY function , and XIST (Xq13), which regulates X-inactivation . Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 179

questions.question: Identify the type of inheritance?
questions.explanation: copy of the mutated gene from one parent is enough to cause the trait or disorder. The trait or disorder will be present in every generation, as affected individuals pass the mutated gene to their offspring. Individuals with one affected parent have a 50% chance of inheriting the trait. For example, if a parent has a dominant genetic disorder like Huntington's disease, there's a 50% chance their child will inherit the disorder. Incorrect Options: Option B - Autosomal Recessive Inheritance: In autosomal recessive inheritance, two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) are required to manifest the trait or disorder. Carriers of a single mutated gene are usually healthy but can pass on the mutation to their offspring. The trait or disorder might skip generations if carriers do not have affected children. When two carriers have a child, there's a 25% chance the child will have the disorder, a 50% chance of being a carrier, and a 25% chance of having neither the disorder nor being a carrier. An example is cystic fibrosis. Option C - X-Linked Dominant Inheritance: X-linked dominant inheritance involves a mutated gene on the X chromosome. A single copy of the mutated gene on one of the X chromosomes is sufficient to cause the trait or disorder in females (since they have two X chromosomes) and in males (who have one X chromosome).

questions.question: A 30-year-old pregnant woman who has the thalassemia trait visits the clinic for genetic counseling. Her husband is also confirmed to have the thalassemia trait. Considering their genetic background, what is the likelihood of their next offspring having thalassemia?
questions.explanation: Punnett square analysis shows that there's a 25% chance for their offspring to inherit two mutated copies of the gene (one from each parent), resulting in thalassemia. There is a 50% chance of inheriting one normal and one mutated gene (being a carrier like the parents), and a 25% chance of inheriting two normal copies of the gene. Incorrect Options: Option A - 100%: This would mean that all of their offspring would definitely have thalassemia, which is not the case. Thalassemia is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder, meaning that both copies of the gene need to carry the mutation for the disorder to manifest. Since both parents have thalassemia trait, they each carry one normal copy of the gene and one mutated copy. Therefore, there is a chance that their offspring may inherit one normal copy from one parent and one mutated copy from the other, resulting in carrying the thalassemia trait, but not necessarily having thalassemia. Option B - 50%: This would imply that each offspring has a 50% chance of having thalassemia. While it's true that each child has a 50% chance of inheriting the mutated gene from either parent, the probability of them having thalassemia depends on both copies of the gene being mutated, which is less likely. Option C - 75%: This would suggest that there's a higher likelihood of having thalassemia than not. However, the probability of an offspring having thalassemia is not this high. It's important to remember that the trait they both have is the heterozygous form (thalassemia trait), which means they each have one normal gene and one mutated gene. This significantly reduces the probability of their offspring having thalassemia

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding the Mendelian mode of inheritance?

options.A: 2/3 rd of Mendelian disorders are autosomal dominant
options.B: 1/3rd of Mendelian disorders are autosomal recessive
options.C: Every 5 th patient has an X-linked recessive disorder
options.D: Every 10 th patient has a Y-linked disorder

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 2/3 rd of Mendelian disorders are autosomal dominant Explanation: Approximately 65% of human monogenic disorders are autosomal dominant , making this the most common Mendelian inheritance pattern. Mendelian Disorders: (Classical inheritance) Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive X-linked dominant X-linked recessive 65% of mendelian disorders are autosomal dominant 25% are autosomal recessive (Option B) 5% are X-linked (Option C) Y-linked are extremely rare, and prevalence is much lower than 1/10 Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 3652 Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 144-146

questions.question: An affected male does not have affected children, but an affected female always has affected children. What is the type of inheritance?
questions.explanation: material exclusively through the maternal line via mitochondria. Mitochondrial DNA is inherited from the mother, and therefore, affected females always pass the mitochondrial gene to all of their children, resulting in all of their children being affected. Affected males do not pass the mitochondrial gene to their children, and they do not have affected children. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: With which pattern of disease inheritance is consanguinity associated?
questions.explanation: the parents. Autosomal recessive diseases are more likely to occur in the offspring of consanguineous couples. This is because the parents may both carry a single copy of a recessive gene mutation, and when they have children together, there is an increased chance of both parents passing on the mutated gene, resulting in the expression of the disease phenotype in the offspring. Incorrect Options: Option B - Autosomal Dominant: Autosomal dominant diseases can occur in the offspring of consanguineous couples, but they are not specifically associated with consanguinity. Autosomal dominant diseases can also arise from de novo mutations or occur in non-consanguineous families. Option C - X-Linked Recessive: X-linked recessive diseases are inherited through the X chromosome. Although consanguinity can increase the likelihood of inheriting X-linked recessive diseases, it is not the characteristic pattern associated with consanguinity. Option D - X-Linked Dominant: X-linked dominant diseases can also occur in the offspring of consanguineous couples, but they are less common and not specifically associated with consanguinity. Reference: Prepladder Notes
